metadata.case_name: Amar Singh and four others v. Custodian-General of Evacuee Property

facts.text: Petitioners are displaced persons who owned land in Chak No. 159-RB, Tahsil Jaranwala, District Lyallpur in Pakistan and were co-sharers in a joint khata owned by evacuees in village Sultanwind, suburb of Amritsar in East Punjab.
On displacement, petitioners were temporarily allotted agricultural land in Sultanwind and in 1949 allotted total 38 standard acres and 13 units of agricultural land on quasi-permanent basis.

Director-General of Relief and Rehabilitation Additional Custodian directed on January 7, 1950, allotment of 142 standard acres and 5 units of suburban land of Amritsar to allottees of Provincial Gardens, necessitating readjustment of allotments in Sultanwind.

Deputy Custodian, Amritsar proposed cancellation of petitioners' allotment on July 31, 1951, approved by Custodian Financial Commissioner, Relief and Rehabilitation on February 6, 1952; passed without notice to petitioners.
Petitioners filed revision under s. 27 of Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 before Custodian-General, dismissed by Deputy Custodian-General on May 1, 1954 after hearing parties.

Partition of India on August 15, 1947 led to mass migrations: about 5 million Non-Muslims from West Punjab to East Punjab; displaced persons left 67 lakh acres in Pakistan, evacuees left 47 lakh acres in East Punjab and Pepsu.
Government introduced quasi-permanent allotments via Press Communique dated February 7, 1948; allotments not conferring ownership or permanent occupancy but maintaining possession.
Petitioners' allotment was on quasi-permanent basis; cancellation undisputedly under Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 and rules.
Petitioners have not obtained sanad under Displaced Persons Compensation and Rehabilitation Rules, 1955.

legal_issues.text: Whether the rights of a quasi-permanent allottee constitute property within the meaning of Arts. 19(1)(f), 31(1) and 31(2) of the Constitution.
Whether the orders of the Custodian and Deputy Custodian-General canceling the quasi-permanent allotment amount to violation of fundamental rights under Arts. 19(1)(f), 31(1) and 31(2).

petitioner_arguments.text: Allotment to petitioners was on quasi-permanent basis acquiring rights constituting property; orders of Custodian and Deputy Custodian-General violate fundamental rights to property under Arts. 19(1)(f), 31(1) and 31(2).
Quasi-permanent allottee entitled to right to possession which is property; treated as owner for various purposes under Punjab laws.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Press Communique Feb 7, 1948; various Punjab Acts and rules

petitioner_arguments.text: Under Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954, entitled to continue in possession and obtain transfer via sanad.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.10, Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954; r.72(2) Rules 1955; Julius v. Lord Bishop of Oxford

respondent_arguments.text: Quasi-permanent allotment does not constitute property; subject to cancellation under Act and rules.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 ss.10,12; rules including July 8, 1949 notification

court_reasoning.text: Detailed historical review of evacuee property laws from 1947 ordinances to 1950 Act shows allotments are grants of use/occupation, initially temporary, later quasi-permanent but subject to wide cancellation powers.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Allottee's interest is provisional, analogous to jus in re aliena, not property itself.

court_reasoning.text: Incidents of quasi-permanent allotment under July 8, 1949 notification: heritable, quiet enjoyment, improvements compensable, exchange/sub-lease allowed but no sale/mortgage; subject to resumption on administrative grounds.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sum total does not constitute ownership or property protected by fundamental rights.

court_reasoning.text: Even post-1952 amendments restrict but do not negate cancellation powers; Displaced Persons Act 1954 allows continued possession but subject to variation/cancellation under s.19.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No indefeasible right to sanad or permanent ownership.

court_reasoning.text: Cancellation was under authority of law creating the rights; ss.28,46 bar challenge; not deprivation without authority of law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Exercise of resumption power inherent in the grant.

holdings.text: Rights of quasi-permanent allottee do not constitute property within Arts. 19(1)(f), 31(1), 31(2); no violation of fundamental rights.
Cancellation orders do not infringe fundamental rights.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dunichand Hakim v. Deputy Commissioner, Deputy Custodian, Evacuee Property, Karnal
precedents_cited.relevance: Refers to Land Resettlement Manual as authoritative on background.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose
precedents_cited.relevance: Observation on wider sense of 'property' under Art. 31(1) not shared by court.

precedents_cited.case_name: Julius v. Lord Bishop of Oxford
precedents_cited.relevance: Principle of mandatory exercise of discretionary power not applicable due to overriding cancellation powers.

precedents_cited.case_name: Suraj Parkash Kapur v. The State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Disagrees that quasi-permanent interest constitutes protected property.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for petition; court holds no violation as no property right.

statutes_cited.name: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 (XXXI of 1950)
statutes_cited.relevance: Vests evacuee property in Custodian; powers of management, allotment, cancellation; bars jurisdiction.

statutes_cited.name: Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954 (XLIV of 1954)
statutes_cited.relevance: Acquisition of evacuee property; allottee continues possession subject to cancellation; compensation pool.

statutes_cited.name: East Punjab Evacuees (Administration of Property) Act, 1947 (XIV of 1947)
East Punjab Displaced Persons (Land Resettlement) Act, 1949 (XXXVI of 1949)
East Punjab Refugees (Registration of Land Claims) Act, 1948 (XII of 1948)
East Punjab Holdings (Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation) Act, 1948 (L of 1948)

outcome.summary: Petition under Art. 32 dismissed holding that quasi-permanent allotment does not constitute property protected by fundamental rights; cancellation lawful under evacuee property laws.

key_quotes.text: The two substantial questions that arise, therefore, for consideration are (1) whether the rights of a quasi-permanent allottee constitute property within the meaning of the articles above referred to, and (2) whether the orders of the Custodian and Deputy Custodian-General canceling the quasi-permanent allotment amount to violation fundamental rights contemplated by the above articles.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Having given our best consideration, we are unable to hold that the interest of a quasi-permanent allottee is property within the concept of that word so as to attract the protection of fundamental rights.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on nature of quasi-permanent rights.

key_quotes.text: In holding that quasi-permanent allotment does not carry with it a fundamental right to property under the Constitution we are not to be supposed as denying or weakening the scope of the rights of the allottee.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies statutory rights remain important despite no constitutional protection.
